Senate version keeps the Estate Tax (just change the threshold). House version has it phase out in 6 years, so I would count it as a YES. The only way the repeal of estate tax could be in the bill on the desk of the President is that the House decides to go to conference and decide to pick fight with Senate on that particular issue. Although it is a red meat issue for Trump supporters, raising the threshold would drastically reduce the number of people affected, and the republican base will understand it as a defacto repeal in their mind. Even picking a fight with the Senate, the House would risk to jeopardize the entire tax bill, rendering its passage before Jan 1, 2018 impossible.
Without cranking the numbers, I would say the chance remains 0%.

Senate Bill doubles but does not remove estate tax. House bill eliminates it with a sunset provision starting 2026. It seems highly probable that they will side with the Senate Bill, hence lowering estimate to 10%

I'm guessing that the House of Representatives will opt for the Senate version of the tax bill as it relates to the estate tax which is to exempt just about everyone but not repeal it entirely as the House version does. But stay tuned as they negotiate the final tweaks.
Senate bill more likely to pass than the House bill, yes? Senate bill does not eliminate the estate tax.

The question itself is ambiguous. If we are to read it to mean a repeal of the estate tax to occur before the end of the year, then the chances are zero. Even if the Trump tax bill passes, it would not fully repeal the estate tax until after 2024 and only immediately increase the taxable ceiling. However, I think that the question is asking something different: whether Trump will sign legislation that repeals the estate tax by the end of year. If that legislation immediately repeals the tax or does so with a sunset provision does not matter so long as it is signed. Interpreted in this way, the question is really “will Trump’s tax agenda pass before the end of the year” for which the odds are a lot better. The combination of the current momentum, having the passed the House, with the Republicans motivation to make it happen before Christmas makes it possible if not probable.
Preliminary odds: 30%
They might achieve a reduction in the rate or an increase in the ceiling, but almost certainly not repeal.

This is a tricky one.  Repealing this tax will significantly enrich his own family and make him even more popular among his plutocratic supporters, these being two important objectives of his presidency.   On the other hand, there will be noticeable resistance from both parties in both chambers to this.   On yet another hand, the Ds have so far been too stupid to figure out how to make political hay out of this proposal.  Bumping up a bit, because why not?

No. 3 in Senate GOP leadership indicates tax reform might not happen until 2018: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-18/no-3-gop-senator-joins-those-opening-door-to-tax-revamp-in-2018. Despite some folks' assumptions this path is fairly easy for the GOP, tax reform will be a very hard thing to pass, especially as they reconcile how to offset significant tax cuts with a ballooning deficit. Oh, and for those counting, the Senate has 34 days left in session this calendar year (https://www.senate.gov/legislative/resources/pdf/2017_calendar.pdf), and the House has 28 (https://www.majorityleader.gov/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/2017_ANNUAL_CALENDAR.pdf). And during that same time, they also need to either pass another CR, or fully fund the government. And since they haven't passed a bipartisan budget agreement to lift sequester caps, that budget has to meet the caps. Of course, they could just kick the can with a CR, but that means no border wall money...

I'm interested in this question because it is one that is emotional for a lot of people on both sides, which would suggest that predictions might be biased and therefore subject to poor predictions. My gut instinct is that the current consensus of 7% is too low.  This would seem to require two things to happen: 
1) Republicans pass a tax bill: given their general ineptitude this year, their track record would suggest that the probability is optimistically maybe 10-20%; but on the other hand they desperately need to pass something before the election year so maybe bump that up to 25%; and they have to pass a budget or a continuing resolution so there's a bit of an incentive;
2) if they pass a tax bill, then the next question is whether it include at least a temporary repeal of the estate tax: 50% This is one of the top priorities of Republican donors and of Trump personally. However, Susan Collins is opposed to repealing the estate tax; and several senators (including Corker and Paul) are opposed to unfunded reductions that lead to deficits so that will complicate matters. On the other hand there are Democrats who would support an Estate Tax repeal, but they are likely to vote in a block against a budget/tax resolution that is rammed through. 
So ... that would work out to something like 10-12%.

They've passed the needed budget legislation so will only need 50 Senate votes, which they may or may not have as long as this is bundled with everything else.  As a freestanding bill, it would pass tomorrow--well, Tuesday.    Frustrated so far in their drive to deprive millions of health insurance, the prez and his wacky band of merrymakers may console themselves with their ability instead to grant hundreds of millions in tax breaks to each other and a few hundred of their close personal friends.     Open to your thoughts on why I am still a Republican.  Probably related to my desire to have the Titanic's deck chairs arranged tidily.

Wow, some pessimists in this room.  First, my own biases: (1) I'm a tax editor, so I HOPE we get tax reform because it will sell a lot of books. (2) I think Trump is an incompetent racist who never really thought he would be President, but here we are. However, he's only one of the moving parts in the tax reform machine. So the shortcomings that I have identified are only partially relevant to my analysis.  So me and my other editors, along with our gaggle of authors (lawyers, accountants, financial planners, and other people that Jimmy Buffet warned us about) have been keeping an eye on the possibility of tax reform, including a repeal of the estate tax, ever since Trump got elected. According to all concerned, The right timeline for doing tax reform was to introduce a bill (maybe more than one) in April or May, kick it around for the summer, do the hard work in the fall, and get it passed sometime in October. For many reasons that didn't happen. So then the plan became to gather at the Reagan ranch and write a bill in August to be introduced after Labor Day. That hasn't happened. Given Hurricane Harvey some delay was understandable, but now we're hearing that a bill will be introduced Sept. 25 (http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/14/trump-tax-reform-big-six-242719), though it seems like they're struggling to even meet that deadline. So, questions: (1) Assuming a bill (and not just a statement of policy positions, but an actual here's-how-we're-changing-the-code bill) gets filed (not just waived around) by Sept. 25-ish, could they pass tax reform? Yes, if they are willing to step on some toes (and they are). It will likely require the rest of the year, and the process of implementing it will make heads explode at the IRS, but it could get done. (2) Will tax reform include a repeal of the estate tax? Yes. First, repealing the estate tax has been an absolute darling of the Republican party for a long time. In fact, they actually did repeal it for one year (2010), and nothing bad happened. This is because next to nobody pays the estate tax. Currently you have to have an estate north of $5 million to even worry about it ($10 million if you're married), and anyone with that kind of money has hired a good estate planner. This means that repealing the estate tax is something the dems are happy to give to the Rs in exchange for something else, and it also means that it won't add too much to the deficit. The hard part about doing tax reform is doing it in a way that gets anything even remotely close to a reasonable score from the CBO. Repealing a tax that all Rs hate and that adds very little revenue? Easy call. (3) So, will they? If Trump was even marginally competent at negotiating Washington's corridors of power, I would put this at 60+%, even at this late date. Politically, this is a must-win, do it for the Gipper (literally), failure-is-not-an-option issue for the Rs. There is enough complexity in tax reform that you can put enough sweeteners in to get some D votes, and this gets a whole lot harder to do in 2018. Think of it this way: If you do it 2017, you can debate until just before Christmas, pass some back-room compromise, and let the IRS sort it out over the next 12 months. But if you push it until 2018, you have an election in early November, and primaries in the spring. So not only do you have two fewer months of debate, any R who goes into primary without having passed tax reform (or anything else of substance, for that matter), is in real trouble from the Bannon Brigade of potential hard-right challengers. And if you end up with too many hard-right mouth breathers running for office, some seats that used to be safe for Rs won't be. Rs absolutely need tax reform for their own political survival. So let's pick some numbers.  If John Kasich was President, I'd go with 75%. With Trump, I'll start at 40% and add the following modifiers:
-Trump is  apparently willing to work with Dems on certain things. If it was earlier in the year, I'd give this +15%, but getting anything through the House that Ds support is tough and adds a lot of delay, so I'll go with +10%.
-Hard-left dems are really mobilized against anything Trump does, and he still hasn't released his tax returns (which is particularly relevant to this debate). -5%
-More bad things can happen (hurricanes, indictments, DPRK nukes Guam, etc.) and tax reform needs some stability -5% So I'll stick with 40% for now. However, if we get past September and we're still screwing around without any hard proposals, it will probably go way down.

There is too little time left in the year to get even a first round of tax reform done, especially now that Trump and the Democrats agreed to revisit the debt ceiling in December, and immigration has taken center stage for at least the next month or two.

The Senate Parliamentarian ruled that FY17 reconciliation procedures end Sep 30, regardless of whether an FY18 budget is passed. Some R's had been eyeing FY17 reconciliation procedures as a means to pass tax overhaul after the failure to repeal ACA. With that option no longer on the table, Congress will have to pass an FY18 budget agreement (or at least FY18 guidance to include the procedures for using reconciliation) to move forward with this option.  WaPo has a good synopsis: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/the-finance-202/2017/09/05/the-finance-202-tax-overhaul-faces-big-hurdles-as-congress-returns/59addb3630fb04264c2a1c99/.

See, here's the thing, Mister President--in our system, members of the legislative branch do not work for you, or for their presiding officer, or even for their party.  Each of them has a separate and absolute constitutional-level right to be there and to do whatever they think is best for those who elected them.  Admittedly this could be as few as 30% of the people who actually live in their constituencies,  and admittedly too many think that whatever is best for their constituency is for them to get re-elected--but nonetheless they don't work for anyone else.  Until somebody squeezes this notion firmly into your head, you will be unable to get anything signficant done that requires a Congressional okey-dokey.  Incidentally, the smart money is not on you in this regard.

The fault lines are as much about lawmakers' parochial concerns as they are about party identity, further complicating the task of cobbling together a majority.

Health care: narrowly focused, potentially affected 20-30 million Americans, comprised 1/6th of US budget - took 68 legislative days to fail (17 in the House, 33 in the Senate, 18 days to move between chambers). Had no major competing legislation. Tax reform: broadly focused, potentially affected 300+ million Americans, foundation of entire US budget - House and Senate have 67 legislative days (48 in the House, 67 in the Senate). Has several major pieces of competing legislation in the form of an FY18 budget resolution, debt ceiling raise, bipartisan budget agreement to raise BCA 2011 caps, etc. Additional factors: GDP growth has not reached WH planning assumptions (nor is it realistically projected to), failure of ACA repeal prevents GOP from factoring those expenditures as cost savings to allow tax breaks, House Freedom Caucus is not really onboard, Democrats are showing a strong unified front, WH can't get out of its own way and wants to come back around to health care again. At this point, it's a question of whether the GOP can get any wins on its legislative agenda, let alone the largest piece that would require some type of bipartisan support (I know reconciliation allows this to be done on a party-line vote, but tell that to the health care effort). We'll see what the Koch brothers can do, but revamping one of the basic functions of the federal government is easier said than done.

However, tax reform also is completely reliant on Congress passing a budget resolution, which will establish the procedures for using reconciliation. Reconciliation is the GOP's best chance to pass tax reform, especially if the plan is to provide significant corporate tax relief.  Given the challenges of health care, the looming debt ceiling crisis, the inability of the House or Senate to pass a budget resolution yet, and the mixed signals coming from the WH, I'm not sure the GOP could accomplish this before January 2019, let alone January 2018.

After healthcare failure, Republicans face similar divisions on tax reform
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-budget-idUSKBN1A30RD

The FY18 House Budget proposal, targeting over $200B in cuts including to Medicare and Social Security, proposes major tax policy rewrites (https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/house-gop-unveils-budget-plan-that-attaches-major-spending-cuts-to-coming-tax-reform-bill/2017/07/18/6e68b679-c63a-4dd1-a3da-e191636946ad_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_gopbudget-606am%3Ahomepage%2Fstory). However, the antagonistic, Freedom Caucus-ish bill is likely to deepen the divide within the GOP between conservatives and moderates. Additionally, increases to the defense caps outlined under the 2011 Budget Control Act requires a bipartisan budget agreement, meaning the GOP would need 8 Senate D's to support these cuts, which is unlikely.  (For clarification, a budget resolution, which this article talks about, is essentially an agreement between House and Senate on overall discretionary spending levels, and is what sets the rules for using reconciliation. A bipartisan budget agreement to relieve pressure from the 2011 BCA caps is usually a 2-yr deal to allow discretionary spending in defense and non-defense to exceed the sequestration levels set forth in the 2011 BCA. Failure to come to agreement would result in sequestration taking effect, with cuts to both defense and non-defense. The non-defense cuts would be spread across the 11 appropriations that comprise non-defense expenditures, where the defense cuts would be spread across DOD. -- Fun fact: the 2011 BCA was created as a forcing mechanism to address the ballooning costs of mandatory spending programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid - the very things that will cause the FY18 budget negotiations to possibly devolve into a government shutdown!) It seems unlikely that such efforts will go anywhere, especially since Sen D's can use their leverage to either enact sequestration or to shut down the government, both of which would look bad for a GOP-controlled WH and Congress (it'll also look bad for the Dems, but Ted Cruz's stunt in 2013 demonstrated the party out of power will suffer less than the party in power). Maintaining at my 0% that Trump signs any legislation for the federal estate tax (or really any tax legislation).

So the WH is starting to put together a plan for tax reform (https://www.axios.com/tax-reform-shocker-the-white-house-actually-has-a-plan-2460447660.html). However, many of the details of overhauling the U.S. tax code will have to be hammered out by the respective congressional committees, which will take time. Another potential spoke in the tire is if Congress fails to pass a budget resolution, which would prevent the GOP from using reconciliation until a resolution passes. Add on to it the House R's are contemplating high risk budget strategies (http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/14/house-republicans-spending-bill-240565), and the path forward for tax reform by the question date is challenging at best.

Good read on the challenges of tax reform: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/the-finance-202/2017/07/12/the-finance-202-tax-overhaul-at-mercy-of-budget-negotiators/59652d94e9b69b7071abcb11/ Buried in the longer article is a brief discussion of the Trump administration attempting to block increased enforcement of estate taxes. However, it is not (yet) attempting to repeal, permanently or temporarily, the estate tax, and Congress has not drafted any legislation to that end.

To start tax reform through reconciliation (and thus only needing 51 votes in the Senate), the Senate has to finish BCRA either through passage or by admitting defeat. And with tax reform really not having any existence beyond a 1-page list of ideas, the process will be long and messy as the GOP tries to reconcile within itself how to best proceed. Using BCRA as a measurement as it will likely stretch into its 5th month in August, and acknowledging delays to pass a budget (or CR) and raise the debt ceiling, tax reform will go into January if not later. I'm impressed by the optimism of this happening this year; I just fail to see a legislative path that accomplishes this before January 1st.

I think this unlikely but still within the realm of political and legislative possibility. The White House needs a legislative win this fall, and I believe it will look to tax reform as the vehicle to achieve that.   A number of states have ended estate tax at the state level and can point to data indicating that the repeal contributed to economic growth, so this aspect of tax reform will have more popular support than ending the AMT or eliminating mortgage interest deduction.  Its still unlikely that a tax reform bill will be signed into law this year given all of the special interests involved, but if such a law is signed this year, I believe it will include an estate tax repeal.

Some good insight into the challenges of tax reform and its interconnection to health care: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/the-finance-202/2017/07/06/the-finance-202-how-committed-is-the-gop-to-tax-cuts-for-the-rich-we-re-about-to-find-out/595d2570e9b69b7071abca80/.

Tax reform, as of now, can be pursued under FY17 reconciliation procedures. FY17 ends 30 Sep, and its unclear if the Reps can continue pursuing after the end of the FY in which it would be enacted. If they cannot, tax reform is not happening. If they can, it's worth looking at the trend of health care. It's been worked on seriously by the House and Senate for the past 4 months, and will likely need all of July to get through if it's ever going to happen. So 5 months of hard legislative work with nothing else major to distract (legislatively). Now let's look at the second half of CY17. July is dedicated to the health care fight. August is recess. September will be passing a budget agreement and likely a CR to keep the government open. October will require raising the debt ceiling to keep the U.S. from defaulting. Realistically, Reps could work tax reform for Oct through mid-Dec (next major recess), which would give them 9 weeks in session for the House and 8 weeks for the Senate. But tax reform seems a pretty heavy lift to accomplish in that time, especially when considering the internal dynamics of Congress. It would require both chambers working together to get something that could pass quickly. However, its more likely each chamber would only have about 4 weeks to draft and pass their version, with a final week for floor votes. Not very likely. Plus that would mean voting before CBO could score it, which could be disastrous for the GOP in the 2018 midterms.  The wiser play here is to wait, address tax reform in the FY18 budget agreement reconciliation procedures, and tackle it fresh in January 2018.

Repealing will make the income for the federal budget significantly lower, and with the CBO already opposing a lot of Trump budget proposals, gridlock in congress may not be so irrelevant. 
it would lead the government to borrow more to offset the lost revenue. Government borrowing “soaks up” capital that would otherwise be available for investment in the economy. In the case of estate-tax repeal, the added government borrowing would more than outweigh any added private saving, leaving the economy no better off and quite possibly worse off. 
Gridlock when negotiating another crucial issue: the U.S. debt ceiling. That's the legal borrowing limit that must be raised or suspended this fall if the United States is to avoid a default on its debt. The debt ceiling is currently set at $19.8 trillion. Debt levels are near that cap and Treasury has begun using special accounting measures to keep outstanding debt just below the limit. But those measures are only expected to last until sometime this fall. 
At that point, if nothing is done, Treasury won't have enough cash and revenue on hand to pay all the country's bills in full and on time.

Again, the only realistic way to achieve this is through reconciliation for FY17. And with each new crisis, the administration changes the agenda. No meaningful movement on tax reform has been realized yet, and there's essentially 11 legislative weeks left in session before FY18. In that time, the Senate needs to confirm an FBI director, workout FY18 approps (or CR), continue the Russia investigation, and determine a path forward on AHCA.  After the start of FY18, there's 9 legislative weeks. And with the CR likely to be the generic short-term one that is passed every year, keeping the government open until the beginning of Dec, the Congress will be busy with negotiating a budget (or new CR), voting to raise the debt ceiling, determining whether processes started under FY17 reconciliation procedures can continue into FY18 (since it's a budget mechanism and not legislation in it's normal sense), still figuring out what to do with AHCA, and maybe holding hearings on some more cabinet positions. So I wouldn't be overly optimistic about the start to FY18. The Republicans can try pushing through new legislation instead, but would have to eliminate the legislative filibuster to do it. While possible (and perhaps enticing), McConnell has, as of now, indicated he's opposed to any such action. And while this may have happened in the past, with a more bipartisan atmosphere, today's environment is not conducive to passing any legislation that even comes near "controversial." And with the Dems remaining solidly opposed to the GOP agenda, the reality is this is essentially postponed until tax reform in earnest begins.

Eliminating Estate Taxes and the AMT
“Estate tax repeal has been on the Republican wish list for decades,” says Gleckman. “There is a good chance it gets repealed.” The right-leaning Tax Foundation says the move could boost growth by nearly 1% over the next decade, as inherited wealth is reinvested. That’s about the same impact as lowering and rejiggering income brackets, but costs about one-sixth as much in lost revenue. But focusing on this issue will let Democrats raise issues of economic inequality. The tax, which applies to estates with assets of $5.49 million this year, affects about 5,000 estates.
There is more bipartisan support for repealing the alternative minimum tax—a separate gauge of tax liability originally designed to keep the wealthy from avoiding paying their fair share but that now affects a broader swath of Americans. One potential obstacle to repeal: The AMT is forecast to bring in more than $350 billion in revenues from 2016 to 2025.

The only realistic way that this gets pushed through in before 1 Jan is by either 1) going nuclear in the Senate to kill the legislative filibuster, thus clearing the way for a simple majority vote, or 2) using reconciliation during FY17, which only requires a simple majority, but is limited by the rules of the reconciliation process, and would likely require the Republicans to put AHCA aside. Going nuclear is simple and allows an expansive bill to be passed, but has far-reaching consequences for the future of American politics and the favorable historical arc of social liberalism. Pursuing this through reconciliation is a vastly more complex route, with unknown time frames, but would preserve the rights of the minority party for when the Republicans eventually return there (a matter of history, not a statement of political preference). Other major legislative items before then: FY18 budget, a bipartisan budget resolution to ease Budget Control Act caps on discretionary funds, healthcare reform, and raising the debt ceiling. Other non-legislative items that can derail tax reform: the Senate Russia investigation, the House Russia investigation, other pending controversies, a WH that is so toxic that legislators spurn the administration, government shutdown, sequestration, default on the national debt, and military intervention in some other country. I put it at 35% because of the allowance of temporary repeals. It's possible that the Senate and House create some temporary bill to suspend the collection of the tax.
